document.masterDocTitle: The genus Litophyton Forskål, 1775 (Octocorallia: Alcyonacea: Nephtheidae) from Australia

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The genus Litophyton Forskål, 1775 (Octocorallia: Alcyonacea: Nephtheidae) from Australia

subSubSection.paragraph:
Nephthya mollis Macfadyen, 1936: 57
, figs 9-10, pl. 5 Fig. 6 ( Australia , GBR, Low lsles).

FIGURE 86 .
Litophyton folium
n. sp. ,
holotype NTM C4128; a, abaxial and lateral point spindles; b, adaxial point spindles; c-d, tentacle rods and scales; e, supporting bundle spindles; f-g, sclerites of surface layer top of stalk; h-i, sclerites of surface layer base of stalk. Scale at a also applies to e, g, i; scale at b also applies to c, f, h.

FIGURE 87 .

n. sp. ,
holotype NTM C4128; a-b, spindles of interior base of stalk; c, tuberculation of interior base stalk spindle.

subSubSection.paragraph: Re-description . The holotype is 11.5 cm high and 10 cm wide, the stalk is 3 cm long ( Fig. 89c ). The polyps are up to 0.8 mm wide and high, grouped in conical catkins.

Polyps . With irregular arrangement of sclerites in eight points ( Fig. 94a ). Abaxial and lateral point sclerites are spindles with simple tubercles and spines, largest present abaxially, up to 0.40 mm long, laterally they are up to 0.15 mm long ( Fig. 94b ). Adaxially there are small scales, similar to those of the tentacles, up to 0.10 mm long ( Fig. 94c ). These small rods also are present on the adaxial side of the polyp stalk. Supporting bundle not projecting, composed of spindles, up to 0.50 mm long, with simple tubercles ( Fig. 94d ).

Surface layer top stalk . Capstans and derivatives of capstans, 0.05-0.10 mm long; spindles and unilaterally spinose spindles are also present, up to 0.35 mm long, with simple tubercles ( Fig. 94e ). Towards the interior a few slightly stouter spindles occur ( Fig. 94f ).

Scale at a also applies to f-i; scale at b also applies to c, e.

subSubSection.paragraph: Interior stalk . Spindles, up to 0.75 mm long, with pointed ends and simple and complex tubercles and some irregular, branched forms ( Fig. 94 i-j).
Distribution . Great Barrier Reef: Erskin Island, Broadhurst reef, Sanctuary reef, Central Reef, Masthead reef, Moore reef, Northwest Island, Rib reef, Darley reef, Cockburn reef.

Remarks . The differences from
L . legiopolypum ( Verseveldt & Alderslade, 1982 )
are small.
L . mollis
has fewer rods in the polyps and the internal stalk spindles are less branched.

L . amboinensis ( Burchardt, 1898 )
from Ambon ( Indonesia ) ( Fig. 97a ) also resembles
L . mollis
but has overall more tuberculated sclerites, polyp spindles are more spiny, and interior base spindles are smaller. ( Fig. 98 ).
NTM C1386, NTM C1475-NTM C1481 were checked with temporary slides only.
